the Pit as a multipurpose venue.{{cite news | url=https://www.abqjournal.com/754473/unm-tries-to-improve-pit-bring-back-ncaas.html | work=[[Albuquerque Journal]] | title=UNM tries to improve Pit, bring back NCAA Tournament | first=Mark | last=Smith | date=April 16, 2016 | accessdate=November 29, 2017}} In recent years it has been the Albuquerque home of [[WWE]] and is the site of the [[Professional Bull Riders]] [[Ty Murray]] Invitational, part of the [[Unleash the Beast Series]]. Both events previously were held at [[Tingley Coliseum]]. ===Concerts=== The Pit has been New Mexico's largest arena since it opened, the largest indoor venue between [[Dallas]] and [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], and also hosts major concert tours. Other entertainers who have appeared at the Pit include [[Led Zeppelin]],Led Zeppelin Concert Timeline, [http://www.ledzeppelin.com/show/may-23-1973 May 23, 1973], ledzeppelin.com [[Queen (band)|Queen]] ([[Queen + Paul Rodgers|with]] [[Paul Rodgers]]), [[Foreigner (band)|Foreigner]], [[Billy Graham]], [[Taylor Swift]], [[Bob Seger]], [[Brad Paisley]], [[George Strait]], [[Billy Joel]], and [[Elton John]].{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|The Pit (arena)}} *[http://www.golobos.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=26000&ATCLID=209096628 WisePies Arena, aka The Pit], New Mexico Official Athletics Site {{University of New Mexico}} {{New Mexico Lobos men's basketball navbox}} {{Mountain West Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pit}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:New Mexico Lobos basketball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Albuquerque, New Mexico]] [[Category:Basketball venues in New Mexico]] [[Category:Music venues in New Mexico]] [[Category:1966 establishments in New Mexico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]]

{{for|the former baseball and football venue in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]|Veterans Stadium}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Veterans Field | fullname = | nickname = | image = | location = [[Laredo, Texas]] | coordinates = {{Coord|27.5197|-99.5093|type:edu_region:US|display=it}} | built = 1950 | opened = 1950[http://unitedleague.org.ismmedia.com/ISM3/std-content/repos/Top/Media%20Guide/MdGdf0411.pdf UBL Records] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926232630/http://unitedleague.org.ismmedia.com/ISM3/std-content/repos/Top/Media%20Guide/MdGdf0411.pdf |date=September 26, 2007 }} | renovated = 2002 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Laredo, Texas|City of Laredo]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[TAMIU]] Dustdevils
[[Tecolotes de los Dos Laredos]] ([[Mexican Baseball League|MBL]]) (1985–2003)
[[Laredo Apaches]] ([[Central Baseball League|CBL]]) (1995)
[[Laredo Broncos]] ([[United League Baseball|ULB]]) (2006–2010) | seating_capacity = [[Baseball]]: 5,000[http://www.visitlaredo.com/page.asp?page=Baseball City of Laredo Baseball Parks] | dimensions = }} '''Veterans Field''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Laredo, Texas]]. Built in 1950, the park was formerly known as '''West Martin Field''', but the field's name was changed to honor the men and women who have served defending America in the armed forces. Home to many teams over the years, it was renovated in 2002, and now seats 5,000 with concessions and two picnic areas. Veterans Field was home to the [[Laredo Broncos]] of [[United League Baseball]]. Veterans Field was also the home to the five-time champion [[Liga Mexicana de Beisbol|Mexican Baseball League]] team [[Tecolotes de los Dos Laredos]] from 1985 to 2003. Veterans Field is also home to the [[Texas A&M International University]] Dustdevils [[college baseball]] team of the [[NCAA]]'s [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] [[Heartland Conference]]. ==References== {{Portal|Texas}} {{Reflist}} {{Laredo, Texas}} {{Texas-baseball-venue-stub}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Laredo, Texas]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Texas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1950]] [[Category:Texas A&M International University]] [[Category:1950 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]]
